meanings.definition: Relating to or denoting a grammatical case that typically marks the direct object of a transitive verb in ergative-absolutive languages.
meanings.sent1: In the ergative-absolutive language, the absolutive case is used for the direct object.
meanings.sent2: The absolutive case is important in ergative-absolutive languages.
meanings.sent3: When learning about the absolutive case, I felt like a language detective.
meanings.sent4: The absolutive case is the key that unlocks the mystery of ergative-absolutive languages.
meanings.sent5: The absolutive case stands out like a bright star in the grammar of ergative-absolutive languages.

meanings.definition: Of or relating to a grammatical construction in which the subject of a transitive verb is treated as the direct object of an intransitive verb.
meanings.sent1: Treating the subject as the direct object in an intransitive verb is an absolutive construction.
meanings.sent2: An absolutive construction can change the perspective of a sentence.
meanings.sent3: The absolutive construction made the grammar lesson surprisingly fun.
meanings.sent4: Using an absolutive construction is like flipping the grammar rules upside down.
meanings.sent5: The absolutive construction paints a vivid picture of language structure.
